headline.main: The Look Is Fast-Food, But the Cuisine Is Serious

docs.abstract: Richard Jay Scholem reviews Paradiso Restaurant and Pizza in Rockville Centre (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: LET'S play ''guess the restaurant.'' On a recent visit to this Long Island spot, the specials included stuffed rabbit medallions in port wine reduction demi-glace; quails in a light, plum-tomato sauce over pappadelle; salmon with wild mushrooms, squash, zucchini and rice pilaf in parchment; soft-shell crabs with mushrooms in a lemon wine sauce; Black Angus rib-eye steak in a Gorgonzola sauce on basmati rice, and 12 soups, including carrot-thyme, ginger-squash and grilled corn bisque. Mirabelle, you say, or Panama Hatties or Louis XVI? No, no and no. Try Paradiso Restaurant and Pizza, a storefront, shopping-center pasta and pizza restaurant at 164 North Village Avenue, Rockville Centre (516-594-4040).

headline.main: Santa Fe Chefs Refine a Sturdy, Lusty Cuisine

docs.abstract: Eric Asimov travel article reviews several restaurants in Santa Fe, New Mexico; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: SANTA FE in autumn is restive. The busy summer season has ended, and the city's high tide of tourism ebbs until the Thanksgiving and Christmas waves. Yet, ask residents about the most beautiful time of the year, and they are likely to cite the fall, when the clear, crystalline light that illuminates the high desert seems polished to an even higher degree of purity by the crisp mountain air. Fall is also harvest time in northern New Mexico. It may seem improbable that much grows in a desert area beyond tumbleweeds and pinon trees, but the Rio Grande supports an ancient network of farms that supply Santa Fe with fresh produce. Visit the city's farmers' market on a Saturday morning and, with the piquant aroma of roasting chilies in the air, you'll see a gorgeous cornucopia of fruits and vegetables, including many heirloom varieties. When this produce finds its way into the kitchens of Santa Fe's restaurants, you've got an opportunity to sample top-flight Southwestern cooking.

headline.main: FRESH CORIANDER FINDS ITS WAY INTO THE AMERICAN CUISINE

docs.lead_paragraph: FIRST it was sun-dried tomatoes and basil; now fresh coriander is cropping up all over. This herb has always been used to flavor Chinese, Latin American or Moroccan dishes, but recently it has become part of the new eclectic American cuisine. It is appearing in many different kinds of sauces for fish and chicken, in tomato salads instead of basil, and even in pesto. Fresh coriander can be added to spicy meatballs, made into a paste with ginger, garlic and chilis and put in curries, or used to flavor beef stews and lamb kebabs. I like to mix it with cumin and lime juice and serve it with roast chicken, or add it to scallop seviche, made with limes, raw onions and chilis. It is also good as a cold dipping sauce for grilled shrimp. Mixed with tomatillos (a Latin American vegetable that looks like a green tomato and tastes like gooseberries) it makes an excellent sauce for chicken or fish that can be served hot or cold.

headline.main: Dining Out; IF IT HAD KEPT TO GERMAN CUISINE...

docs.lead_paragraph: WITH a name like the Jolly Swagman, there is no question that this restaurant in Hicksville is Australian. Less obviously, it is also German. A good measure of Continental cooking is also included. Of the cuisines it offers, the German is the most successful. In fact, if the kitchen concentrated on only German cooking, eliminating the Australian dishes (or substantially improving them), the restaurant would clearly deserve one star. The restaurant, in a house, is white stucco with dogwood used for wainscoting, booths, ceiling beams, ornamental railings and the bar. What isn't dark wood is dark brown leatherette. That includes the tablecloths, a singular off note in a decorating scheme that is clubby and handsomely attractive. In the center of the room is a large bar that seems to do an extremely good business. The varied assortment of domestic and imported beers on tap may be a factor. But the cocktails made with lollipop-sweet fruit juices are less appealing.

headline.main: Haute Cuisine Cooking Taught in a Rural Gourmet Shop

byline.original: By EMMA MAI EWING Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAINVILLE Businessmen, career women, housewives, young mothers, grandmothers and a teen-age girl are among the students enrolled in a haute cuisine cooking school in this rural Hunterdon County hamlet.
